translated: Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, fascicle 100
seventy-four
composed by five hundred great arhats and others
tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully received
refers to parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth.ğŸ”½parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice.
parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice.
those who ascend to the peak of existence.ğŸ”½do the five encompass all?
are all encompassed by the five?
Having understood the text and its meaning in this way, one should extensively distinguish them.
Question: Why was this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to distinguish the meaning of the sÅ«tras.
As the sÅ«tras say, there are five non-returners.
That is, parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
And so on, in detail.
Although that sÅ«tra explains it in this way,
it does not clarify whether the five encompass all,
or whether all are encompassed by the five.
It also has not yet revealed the distinctions of superiority and inferiority.
Now, wishing to fully clarify this, this treatise is composed.
Do the five subsume all, or do all subsume the five?
The answer is: all subsume the five,
but the five do not subsume all.
What is not subsumed?
It refers to parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present life,
and non-returners who go to the formless realm.
Here, many are not the five,
so all subsume the five, but the five do not subsume all.
It is like a large vessel covering a small vessel, but not the small vessel covering the large one.
All refers to the seven non-returners, namely the previous five,
parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present life,
and non-returners who go to the formless realm.
Among them, the latter two are not subsumed by the five, so they are called many.
Question: There are also those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without determination,
that is, some attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the desire realm,ğŸ”½some attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the form realm,
and some attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the formless realm.
Why is this not mentioned here?
Answer: It should be mentioned, but since it is not mentioned, we should know that this meaning is incomplete.
Moreover, they are included in the seven non-returners, so they are not explained separately.ğŸ”½If they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the desire realm,
they are included in those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in this very life.
Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the form realm are included in the five non-returners.
Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the formless realm are included in the non-returners who go to the formless realm.
Question: There are also those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through rebirth.
That is to say, they may attain the fruit of non-returner either from the stage of up to seven rebirths,
or from the stage of the family-to-family,ğŸ”½or from the stage of the once-returner,
or from the stage of the single interval.
Having attained that fruit, they will definitely attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in this very life.
They are not those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in this very life.
Why is it so? Because a scripture says, What is meant by those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in this very life?
It means attaining the fruit of stream-entry in this very life,
and then eliminating the remaining bonds to attain the fruits of once-returner, non-returner, and arhat.
For this reason, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through rebirth are not included in the seven.
Why is this not explained here?
Answer: What should be explained but is not should be understood as having a remainder.
Furthermore, they attain the fruit of non-returner by being disgusted with rebirth.
After that, in how much time do they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a?
Because the time in between is extremely short,
it does not allow for the establishment [of a stage], therefore it is not mentioned.
Furthermore, they are also included within parinirvÄá¹‡a in this very life, therefore they are not mentioned separately.
Because they attain the fruit of non-returner in this life,
and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in this very life.
Between parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state and parinirvÄá¹‡a at birth, which is superior?
If they abide in the same level of severance, then parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state is superior.
If parinirvÄá¹‡a at birth has more severances of bonds, then that is superior.
This means that if these two non-returners are both bound to the first meditative absorption,
up to if they both sever the bonds of the first eight stages of the fourth meditative absorption,
then parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state is superior for three reasons.
First, they experience little suffering. This one experiences the suffering of one existence,
while that one experiences the suffering of two existences.
Second, they quickly extinguish the fire of afflictions.
Third, they quickly abandon the burden of the aggregates.
If parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state is bound by the first dhyÄna,
up to cutting off the seventh category of fetters of the fourth dhyÄna,
parinirvÄá¹‡a at birth cuts off the first category of fetters of the first dhyÄna,
up to cutting off the eighth category of fetters of the fourth dhyÄna,
then parinirvÄá¹‡a at birth is superior due to one thing,
namely abiding in much cutting off.
ParinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state,
up to the highest stream,
going to the peak of existence,
what is superior?
Answer: If abiding in equal cutting off, then parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state is superior.
If going to the highest stream and going to the peak of existence with much cutting off of fetters, then that is superior.
Namely, parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
If compared with parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice and parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice,
all are explained as compared with parinirvÄá¹‡a at birth.
If compared with the highest stream going to the peak of existence, then there is a difference in suffering experienced.
Namely, this one only experiences the suffering of one existence,
while that one experiences the suffering of at least four existences.
The rest is explained as before.
Thus, one attains parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth.
Up to those of the highest stream who go to the peak of existence and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a with exertion.
Up to those of the highest stream who go to the peak of existence and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without exertion. Which is superior, going to the peak of existence?
Answer: If abiding in the same severance, then attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth and so forth are superior.
If attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a with exertion and so forth sever many bonds, then those are superior.
That is to say, these non-returners, according to what they correspond to,
if both possess the bonds of the first meditative absorption,
up to if both sever the bonds prior to the ninth category of the fourth meditative absorption,
then attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth is superior to attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a with exertion by one thing,
that is, attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth has the path of diligent practice and the path of rapid progress,
while attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a with exertion only has the path of diligent practice and lacks the path of rapid progress.
In attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a without exertion, it is superior by two things,
because it lacks the path of diligent practice and also lacks the path of rapid progress.
Those who go upstream to the peak of existence are superior to those who attain nirvana without practice by one thing.
They experience less suffering, experiencing two existences of suffering.
They experience the least suffering, experiencing four existences of suffering.
Those who attain nirvana through practice are superior to those who attain nirvana without practice by one thing.
They have the path of effort.
Both are without.ğŸ”½Those who go upstream to the peak of existence are superior to those who attain nirvana without practice by one thing.
Those who attain nirvana without practice are also superior to those who go upstream to the peak of existence by one thing.
All are as explained above.
If those who attain nirvana through birth, etc. are bound by the first meditation,
up to cutting off the seventh category of bonds of the fourth meditation,
those who attain nirvana through practice, etc. cut off one category of bonds of the first meditation,
up to cutting off the eighth category of bonds of the fourth meditation.
Then there are those who attain nirvana through practice, etc.
Those who attain nirvana through practice, etc. are superior to those who attain nirvana through birth, etc. by one thing.
That is, they abide in many severances.
Furthermore, the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya says:
There are five types of non-returners.
Namely, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state,
up to those who go to the peak of existence.
What is meant by attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state?
It means that a certain person has already severed and completely known the five lower fetters in the previous birth.
He has not yet severed and completely known the five higher fetters.
He creates and increases karma that leads to rebirth in the form realm.
He does not create and increase karma that leads to rebirth in the desire realm.
After his life ends, he gives rise to an intermediate existence in the form realm.
He abides in that intermediate existence and attains this kind of undefiled path.
By the power of this path, he further severs the remaining fetters.
In the nirvÄá¹‡a realm without remainder, he attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
This is called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state. Why is it called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state?
It is because this person has already passed beyond the desire realm,
but has not yet reached the form realm. He abides in that intermediate existence and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a, therefore it is called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Furthermore, this pudgala has sharp faculties and soft afflictions,
and is able to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, therefore it is called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Furthermore, this pudgala first attains a mind with thought,
immediately after the mind with thought he attains a learner's mind,ğŸ”½immediately after the learner's mind he attains a post-learner's mind,
immediately after the post-learner's mind he attains a mind that is neither a learner's nor a post-learner's mind,
and he attains parinirvÄá¹‡a while abiding in that mind, therefore it is called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Question: What is the difference between this and the other kinds of desire?
Answer: The difference in desire is from the other noble ones.
That is to say, other noble ones immediately after a learner's mind either give rise to a post-learner's mind,
or give rise to a mind that is neither a learner's nor a post-learner's mind.
This is not so. Immediately after a learner's mind, they necessarily give rise to a post-learner's mind.
Other noble ones immediately after a mind that is neither a learner's nor a post-learner's mind either attain parinirvÄá¹‡a,
or give rise to a post-learner's mind again.
This is not so.
Immediately after a mind that is neither a learner's nor a post-learner's mind, they definitely attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Because other noble ones frequently manifest the noble path in the present.
This [noble one] does not frequently manifest it.
What is meant by attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth?
It refers to a certain person.
In a previous life, they have already severed and completely known the five lower fetters.
They have not yet severed and completely known the five higher fetters.ğŸ”½They create and increase karma that results in rebirth in the next life.
They create and increase karma that results in rebirth in the present life.
After their life ends, they give rise to the intermediate existence of the form realm and are reborn in the heavens of the form realm.
Soon after being reborn, they attain this kind of undefiled path.
By the power of this path, they further sever the remaining fetters.
In the nirvÄá¹‡a realm with remainder, they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
This is called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth.
Why is it called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth?
It is because this person.
Soon after being reborn, they attain the fruit of arhatship and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore it is called attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth.
Furthermore, this person.
Having been born there for not a long time, they attain the fruit of arhatship.
They exhaust their life span and then enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore it is called birth parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Question: If they enter parinirvÄá¹‡a only after exhausting their life span,
why is it called birth parinirvÄá¹‡a?
Answer: It is said based on the nirvÄá¹‡a of afflictions,
not the nirvÄá¹‡a of aggregates, so there is no fault.
What is parinirvÄá¹‡a with exertion?
It refers to a certain person who in a previous life relied on the path with exertion, always applied attention,
relied on samÄdhi without ceasing effort,
had already severed and completely known the five lower fetters,
had not yet severed or completely known the five higher fetters,
created and increased karma leading to rebirth in the next life,
and karma leading to rebirth in the next existence.
After their life ended, they gave rise to an intermediate existence in the form realm and were born in the heavens of the form realm.
After being born for a long time,
they again relied on the path with exertion,
always applied attention,
relied on samÄdhi without ceasing effort, and further severed the remaining fetters.
They attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the realm with remainder.
This is called parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice.
Question: Why is it called parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice?
Answer: Because this person, by means of the path with practice,
Cleanses away the remaining afflictions and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore it is called parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice.
Moreover, this person, by means of the path with practice, attains the fruit of arhatship.
And attains parinirvÄá¹‡a at the end of his life.
Therefore it is called parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice.
Moreover, this person, relying on the conditioned path with characteristics,
Cleanses away the remaining bonds and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore it is called parinirvÄá¹‡a with practice.
What is parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice?
It is said that in a previous life, this person, by means of the path without practice, did not constantly apply his mind.
Relying on the samÄdhi of cessation and exertion,ğŸ”½He had already severed and completely known the five lower bonds.
He had not yet severed and completely known the five upper bonds.
Creating and increasing karma that accords with rebirth in the present life.
Karma that accords with rebirth in the next life.
After their life ends, they give rise to the intermediate existence of the form realm and are born in the heavens of the form realm.
After being born for a long time,
they again rely on the path without practice and do not constantly apply their minds.
Relying on the samÄdhi of cessation and exertion, they eliminate the remaining bonds.
They attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the nirvÄá¹‡a realm with remainder.
This is called parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice.
Why is it called parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice?
Answer: This person, by the path without practice,
eliminates the remaining afflictions and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore it is called parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice.
Moreover, this person, by the path without practice, attains the fruit of arhatship.
They attain parinirvÄá¹‡a at the end of their life span.
Therefore it is called parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice.
Moreover, this person, relying on the unconditioned path,
eliminates the remaining bonds and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore it is called parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice.
How does one who goes upstream go to the peak of existence?
It is said that a certain person has already cut off and completely known the five lower fetters in a previous life.
He has not yet cut off and completely known the five higher fetters.
He attains the four mundane concentrations.
When he is about to die, he regresses from the upper three concentrations and abides in the first concentration.
Due to the craving for that and the karma of that realm that produces and increases the karma to be experienced in the next life,
and the karma to be experienced in the subsequent life,
he dies and gives rise to the intermediate existence of the form realm, and is born in the BrahmakÄyika heaven.
Having been born, he is able to enter the second mundane concentration.
Due to the craving for that and the karma of that realm,
he produces and increases the karma to be experienced in the next life,
and the karma to be experienced in the subsequent life,
he dies and is born in the Ä€bhÄsvara heaven.
Having been born, he is able to enter the third mundane concentration.
Due to the craving for that and the karma of that realm, he dies and is born in the Åšubhaká¹›tsna heaven.
Having been born there, they are able to enter the worldly fourth dhyÄna.
Due to the craving for that, they die from there and are born in the Bá¹›hatphala heaven.
Having been born there, they are able to arouse the inferior mixed worldly fourth dhyÄna.
Due to the craving for that, they die from there and are born in the Avá¹›ha heaven.
In this way, up to the other four grades of mixed worldly fourth dhyÄna.
They are born in the other four heavens in sequence.
This is called the upward stream going to the peak of existence.
Question: Why is it called the upward stream going to the peak of existence?
Answer: There are two kinds of streams.
One is the craving for birth and death.
The other is the karma for future existence.
This pudgala has not yet cut off or fully known both kinds of streams.
Because of this as a condition and as a cause,ğŸ”½he goes up, follows up,
goes up and follows up,
experiences up, follows up,
streams up, and follows up.
Therefore it is called the upward stream going to the peak of existence.
Furthermore, this person only practices the superior path, not the inferior path, and attains the definite superior, excellent, and supreme state.
And is born in that state, entering that concentration and experiencing that birth.
Therefore, it is called going to the peak of existence as an upper stream.
Furthermore, this person is called upper stream because they are born in the upper realms and cause the continuity of upper births.
Question: Do ordinary beings also go to the upper realms, are born in the upper realms, and cause the continuity of upper births?
Why are they not called upper stream?
Answer: If one only goes to the upper realms and not to the lower realms, they are called upper stream.
Because ordinary beings go to both the upper and lower realms, they are not called upper stream.
Some say:
If one goes to the upper realms without obstruction in all places, they are called upper stream.
Because ordinary beings cannot go to all places without obstruction, they are not called upper stream.
Because they are obstructed in the Pure Abodes.
Question: Are the noble ones who go to the upper realms also obstructed in two places?
Namely, the Great Brahma King and the place of non-perception.
Why are they called upper stream?
Answer: They have no separate place, because they are included in the two places of BrahmapÄrá¹£ada and Brhatphala.
They are still called omnipresent.
Some say:
If the upper stream can transcend the realms and attain the fruits,
Those who permanently sever the five lower fetters are called the upper stream.
Although ordinary beings can transcend the realms, they do not attain the fruits,
And they also do not permanently sever the five lower fetters, so they are not called the upper stream.
Some say:
Those who possess the three kinds of streams are called the upper stream.
Namely, karma, afflictions, and the noble path.
Ordinary beings only have the streams of karma and afflictions, not the stream of the noble path, so they are not called the upper stream.
Furthermore, the upper stream is of two kinds.
One practices in the form realm,
And the other practices in the formless realm.ğŸ”½Those who practice in the form realm go up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven.
Those who practice in the formless realm go up to the Naivasaá¹ƒjÃ±ÄnÄsaá¹ƒjÃ±Äyatana Heaven.
Moreover, those who practice in the form realm have mixed cultivation of the dhyÄnas,
While those who practice in the formless realm do not have mixed cultivation of the dhyÄnas.
Furthermore, there are three types of those who go upstream.
The first is the complete overcomer, the second is the half overcomer, and the third is the one who dies in all places.
The complete overcomer means one who dies in the desire realm and is reborn in the Brahma assembly heaven.
After dying in the Brahma assembly heaven, one is reborn in the ultimate form heaven,
or in the neither perception nor non-perception heaven, and then attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The half overcomer means one who dies in the desire realm and is reborn in the Brahma assembly heaven.
After dying in the Brahma assembly heaven, one is reborn in one, two, three, four, or five of the remaining heavens above,
up to or only surpassing one place and being reborn in the rest, and then is reborn in the ultimate form heaven,
or in the neither perception nor non-perception heaven, and then attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The one who dies in all places means one who dies in the desire realm and is reborn in the Brahma assembly heaven.
After dying in the Brahma assembly heaven, one is reborn in the Brahma preliminary heaven, and in this order is reborn in the remaining places up to the fruit of abundance heaven.
Above this, there are two different paths.
One enters the pure abodes,
and the other enters the formless realm.
Those who enter the Pure Abodes die in the Heaven of Extensive Rewards and are reborn in the Heaven of No Affliction.
In succession, they are reborn in the Heaven of Ultimate Form and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Those who enter the formless realms die in the Heaven of Extensive Rewards and are reborn in the Sphere of Infinite Space.
In succession, they are reborn in the Sphere of Neither Perception nor Non-Perception and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Just as there are two separate paths for dying in all realms,
one should know that the same is true for complete transcendence and partial transcendence.
Question: Which upper stream enters the Pure Abodes?
Which upper stream enters the formless realms?
Answer: There are two kinds of upper stream, namely those who practice vipaÅ›yanÄ and those who practice Å›amatha.
Those who practice vipaÅ›yanÄ enter the Pure Abodes.
Those who practice Å›amatha enter the formless realms.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of upper stream, namely those who delight in superior samÄdhi and those who delight in superior rebirth.
Those who delight in superior samÄdhi enter the Pure Abodes.
Those who delight in superior rebirth enter the formless realms.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of upper stream, namely those who delight in ascertainment and those who delight in tranquility.
Those who delight in ascertainment enter the Pure Abodes.
Those who delight in tranquility enter the formless realm.
Furthermore, there are two types of upper stream: those who mix and those who do not mix.
Those who mix enter the pure abodes.
Those who do not mix enter the formless realm.
Moreover, in all places where the upper stream dies and is reborn, there is that which is manifested by coming but not going.
There is that which is manifested by going but not coming.
There is that which is manifested by both coming and going.
There is that which is manifested by coming but not going.
This refers to being born in the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven or the neither perception nor non-perception heaven.
That which is manifested by going but not coming
refers to being born in the BrahmakÄyika heaven.
That which is manifested by both coming and going
refers to being born in the intermediate abodes.
That which is manifested neither by coming nor going does not exist.
It is as explained above that one who goes to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven
first attains the mundane four meditative absorptions,
and later regresses and abides in the first meditative absorption.
As for one who goes to the neither perception nor non-perception heaven,
one also first attains the mundane four formless [absorptions].
Later, do they regress and abide in the first dhyÄna or not?
Answer: There are also such cases.
It is like first attaining the worldly four dhyÄnas.
Later, regressing and abiding in the first dhyÄna, they end their life and are reborn in the BrahmÄ heaven.
Gradually, they are reborn up to the ultimate form heaven.
In this way, there are also those who first attain the worldly four dhyÄnas and four formless [absorptions].
Later, regressing and abiding in the first dhyÄna, they end their life and are reborn in the BrahmÄ heaven.
Gradually, they are reborn up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
However, this is not necessarily so.
Why is it that they do not speak of regressing from the first dhyÄna?
Answer: There is no one who regresses from the first dhyÄna and ends their life. Therefore it is not mentioned.
Moreover, this shows the distinctions of the non-returners. Those who regress from the first dhyÄna are not non-returners. Therefore it is not mentioned.
It is said that regressing and abiding in the first dhyÄna, one is born in the BrahmÄ assembly heaven, either as a complete overcomer or a half overcomer.
All places end in the upper stream.
If they regress and abide in the second dhyÄna, they are born in the heaven of lesser light.
Retrogression and abiding in the third meditative absorption, one is born among the Heaven of Minor Splendor.
Retrogression and abiding in the fourth meditative absorption, one is born among the Heaven of No Clouds and so forth.
They also can be completely or partially transcendent.
Can all those who die in all places be those who go upstream?
Answer: Some say they cannot.
Because one who is born in the Brahma world does not lack a place to be reborn among those who do not return to the upper realms.
Based on that, completely or partially transcendent are established.
If one retrogresses and is born in the upper realms, the place is then lacking.
Therefore, completely transcendent and so forth are not established based on that.
Some say:
They are also called partially transcendent because they transcend a small part of the intermediate places.
Some say:
They are also called all three kinds. They say that from the desire realm, dying and being born anywhere,
in the upper realms where one should be reborn, one can also establish completely or partially transcendent and dying in all places.
Question: If a non-returner dies in the desire realm and is born in the formless realm, can they also be completely or partially transcendent and so forth?
Answer: Some say they cannot.
Some say:
They are also called half-leapers.
Some say:
They are also fully called the three types. The reasons for this are all as explained above.
Question: As for going to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven as an upward-flowing one,
One must first attain the four meditations and regress to be born in the BrahmÄ world,ğŸ”½And then one can go to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven.
When going to the BhavÄgra heaven as an upward-flowing one,
One must also first attain the four formless concentrations and regress to be born in the BrahmÄ world,
And then one can go to the BhavÄgra heaven.
Answer: It is not necessarily so.
Because one who is born in the form realm cannot initially give rise to the mixed cultivation of the meditative absorptions.
One must in the desire realm have previously given rise to [the mixed cultivation] and now again cultivate it further in order to be able to go to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven.
One who is born in the formless realm has no such superior type of karma.
One must in the desire realm have previously given rise to [the mixed cultivation] and now again cultivate it further in order to be able to be born in the peak of existence.
Therefore, one who goes to the peak of existence, if one has previously attained the formless realm and regressed,
If one first does not attain it, then when one dies from the desire realm and is born in the Brahma assembly heaven, one can all go to the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
Question: Is what is said about the upper stream only faith and understanding?
Or is it also the case that there is attainment through views?
Answer: If one does not regress from the upper concentration and moves upwards, this is common to both kinds.
If one regresses from the upper concentration and moves upwards, it is only faith and understanding.
Furthermore, even if one regresses from the upper concentration and moves upwards, it is common to both kinds.
Question: How does one who has attained through views regress?
Answer: He is not originally one who has attained through views.
But after regressing, before his life ends, he cultivates the faculties from faith and understanding and becomes one who has attained through views.
Then, after his life ends, he is born in the upper realm because he moves upwards.
Question: Is there parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle in the desire realm as there is in the form realm?
Answer: No.
Question: Why is that?
Answer: The desire realm is an indeterminate realm, not a stage of cultivation, not a stage of separation from defilements, and has many faults, calamities, and obstacles.
Even when abiding in the fundamental [stages], it is still difficult to attain the fruits.
How much more so for one with a subtle and inferior body in the intermediate state?
The form realm is not like this, therefore one abiding in the intermediate state can attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, if one abiding in the desire realm attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, then one would be able to transcend the three realms based on the intermediate state.
However, there is no one who can transcend the three realms based on a body in the intermediate state.
Moreover, if one abiding in the desire realm attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state,
then one would be able to sever the afflictions of the three realms in the intermediate state.
However, there is no one who can sever the afflictions of the three realms based on a body in the intermediate state.
Moreover, if one abiding in the desire realm attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, then one would be able to sever both unwholesome and indeterminate afflictions in the intermediate state.
However, there is no one who can sever both unwholesome and indeterminate afflictions based on a body in the intermediate state.

Moreover, if one abiding in the desire realm attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, then one would be able to realize either the second or third fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
However, in the state of non-abiding, there are those who can realize either the second or third fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a with a body.
For this reason, only in the form realm is there parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, and not in the desire realm.
Furthermore, one who attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state must have already been free from the defilements of the desire realm in a previous life.
One who has already been free from the defilements of the desire realm will certainly not give rise to an intermediate state body of the desire realm.
Therefore, there is no parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state in the desire realm.
Furthermore, the afflictions and karma of the desire realm are heavy.
It is not possible to eliminate and sever them with a weak and inferior body in the intermediate state.
Furthermore, the intermediate state is not the basis for attaining the fruit of non-returner.
It is only the basis for attaining the fruit of arhatship.
Furthermore, in the desire realm, the intermediate state body is certainly unable to give rise to the manifestation of the holy path because it is weak and inferior.
This is not so in the form realm.
For this reason, there is no parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state in the desire realm.

Furthermore, the intermediate state body, which is weak and inferior, is only able to give rise to the manifestation of the holy path of its own fundamental stage, not the stage of preparation, etc., because it is difficult to give rise to.
If there were parinirvÄá¹‡a in the desire realm, it would be the opposite of this, so it definitely does not exist.
Moreover, there are afflictions that are opposed and concordant in the desire realm.
There are afflictions of the six external sense bases, afflictions that can lead to two fruits,
afflictions associated with shamelessness and lack of conscience,
and various miscellaneous secondary afflictions such as anger.
They are difficult to destroy, difficult to eliminate, difficult to transcend, and difficult to leave behind.
Dwelling in the fundamental existence, even with great effort,
it is still difficult to remove and eliminate, let alone in the intermediate state.
Therefore there is no parinirvÄá¹‡a in the desire realm.
Moreover, one must have already cultivated the nine categories of antidotes in order to be able to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Since the intermediate state in the desire realm has definitely not yet cultivated the nine categories of antidotes, the intermediate state there does not attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Question: Just as one who dies in the desire realm and receives an intermediate state of the form realm attains parinirvÄá¹‡a,
is it also the case that one who dies in the form realm and receives an intermediate state of the form realm also attains parinirvÄá¹‡a?
Answer: No.
Why is it so?
They are extremely disgusted with the body of the desire realm, which is full of suffering, obstacles, and calamities.
Having abandoned it, when the intermediate existence of the form realm appears before them,
they also become disgusted with the long-lasting ripening that is to be received in the future, and then enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The form realm does not have such calamities and extremely disgusting things that cause disgust.
Just as in the prior existence, there is an obstacle due to conditions, and one does not enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Now, the intermediate existence is also like this.
Therefore, the intermediate existence that arises from death in that realm does not enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Furthermore, if one who dies in the form realm and enters parinirvÄá¹‡a in that intermediate existence
should also be called one who goes upstream, then the five non-returners would become confused.
That is to say, there is no reason for distinction.
Only those who die in the desire realm and enter parinirvÄá¹‡a while dwelling in the intermediate existence are called those who enter parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Not those who die in the form realm.
Moreover, there is no reason for those who go from there to a higher realm to not be called those who go upstream.
Because of this fault, their intermediate existence does not enter nirvana.
Question: If one who dies in the desire realm and gives rise to an intermediate existence of the form realm attains nirvana due to aversion,
why does one not attain nirvana in the original existence of the desire realm?
Because of increased aversion.
Answer: They abide in the original existence, attain the fruit of non-returner, and then complete the practice for the fruit of arhatship.
When the holy path has not yet been aroused, they immediately die.
Therefore, by the power of the previous [practice], they are able to advance and sever the remaining bonds in the intermediate existence and enter nirvana.
Question: Why do they not arouse the holy path but immediately die when the practice is completed?
Answer: It is because their life is exhausted, or their karma is exhausted, or their blessings are exhausted, or they are harmed by others, or for the sake of benefiting others,
or they encounter evil conditions unexpectedly and are unable to arouse the holy path but immediately die.
Some say:
They have attained the fruit of non-returner.
When the subsequent practice is about to be completed, they encounter a long illness.
Or they lack the necessary requisites.
Or they encounter various difficult circumstances such as life-threatening situations, and are unable to exhaust their defilements. They continue on until they reach the end of their life.

Having obtained the new aggregates, faculties, and great elements of the form realm's intermediate state, due to the power of the dominant influence of the new aggregates, faculties, and great elements,
they are quickly able to induce the present manifestation of the noble path, advance to sever the remaining bonds, and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Question: If one dies in the desire realm and is reborn in the formless realm, are there also those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through birth, etc.?
Answer: There are.
Those who die in the desire realm and are reborn in the two upper realms, without being reborn again, attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Wherever they are, in that very birth they can all establish the three types of parinirvÄá¹‡a through birth, etc., and the two types of parinirvÄá¹‡a through birth.
Because those above, wherever they are, can all be established as the upper stream.
Question: The upper stream who delights in wisdom does not reach the peak of existence.
The upper stream who delights in concentration does not reach the summit of existence.
Can those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the lower realms also be called the two types of upper stream who delight in wisdom and concentration?
Answer: They also obtain the names of the two types according to their kind.
However, it is said that those who delight in wisdom go to the peak of existence,ğŸ”½and those who delight in concentration go to the summit of existence.
This is said based on the ultimate place,
because there is no further place to go beyond this.
It is like how a stream-enterer is called one who will be reborn at the most seven times,

but those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state are also given this name. It is the same for this. Question: Why do the noble ones in the two upper realms only experience one birth in each place of rebirth, but not so in the desire realm?
Answer: The desire realm is an indeterminate realm, a realm of confusion, where the various afflictions and karmas mutually suppress and confuse each other, without any fixed rules.
Therefore, it causes the noble ones to be reborn from lower to higher, and from higher to lower.
Or to experience many births in one place.
The form and formless realms are realms of concentration, not realms of confusion.
The various afflictions and karmas do not mutually suppress and confuse each other, and there are fixed rules.
Therefore, it causes the noble ones to only go up, not down, and to experience one birth in one place.
Moreover, the noble ones reborn in the desire realm are not called non-returners.
but it is called â€œat most seven rebirthsâ€ and so on. Therefore, one is reborn in higher or lower realms, but not reborn in the same place.
The noble one who is reborn in the upper realms is called a non-returner. Therefore, one is only reborn in the upper realms, and not reborn again.
For this reason, the meaning of non-returner is fulfilled.
One is not even reborn in one's original place, let alone returning to be reborn in a lower realm.
Furthermore, there are innumerable types of non-returners in detail.
Now, we will distinguish the five types who proceed to the form realm.
It should be known that this is said to be one based on the establishment of realms.
It is said to be two based on the establishment of birth and non-birth.
It is said to be five based on the establishment of distinctions in states.
That is, parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, up to the stream-enterer who goes to the peak of existence.
This is said to be fifteen based on the establishment of faculties.
That is, faculties of lower, middle, and upper.
It is said to be twenty based on the establishment of five stages.
That is, the first concentration up to the fourth concentration.
It is said to be thirty based on the establishment of five types of nature.
That is, the five types of faculties of those of the nature of regression, up to those of the nature of immovability.
Each is established in five places, so it is said to be eighty.
That is, from the BrahmakÄyika gods up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha gods.
Each is of five types of nature and established in faculties, so it is said to be ninety.
That is, the lower, middle, and upper faculties of those of the nature of regression.
Each has five, up to those of the nature of immovability are also like this.
The establishment of the types of realms is said to be one hundred and twenty.
That is, the six types of nature of the first dhyÄna each have five, up to the fourth dhyÄna is also like this.
The establishment of the types of realms and faculties is said to be three hundred and sixty.
That is, the three faculties of the five types of nature of the six types of nature of the first dhyÄna each have five, up to the fourth dhyÄna is also like this.
The establishment of the types of realms is said to be four hundred and eighty.
That is, the five of each of the six types of nature of the BrahmakÄyika gods up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha gods are also like this.
The establishment of the types of realms, nature, and faculties is said to be one thousand four hundred and forty.
That is to say, the BrahmakÄyika gods have six natures and three faculties each, and so on up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha gods, which are also like this.
Because of the establishment of realms, types, natures, and faculties, it is said to be twelve thousand nine hundred and sixty.
That is to say, the previous one thousand four hundred and forty each have nine kinds of distinctions in detachment.
Furthermore, the establishment of distinctions in parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle also has many kinds.
That is to say, because of realms, it is said to be one.
Because of faculties, it is said to be three.
Because of stages, it is said to be four.
Because of types, it is said to be six.
Because of detachment, it is said to be nine.
Because of realms, it is said to be sixteen.
Because of types and faculties, it is said to be eighteen.
Because of stages and types, it is said to be twenty-four.
Because of stages and detachment, it is said to be thirty-six.
Because of stages, types, and faculties, it is said to be seventy-two.
Because of realms and types, it is said to be ninety-six.
Because of stages, detachment, and faculties, it is said to be one hundred and eight.
Because of realms and detachment, it is said to be one hundred and forty-four.
Because of the different types, degrees of detachment, and faculties, there are 162.
Because of the different stages, types, and degrees of detachment, there are 216.ğŸ”½Because of the different abodes, types, and faculties, there are 288.
Because of the different stages, types, faculties, and degrees of detachment, there are 648.
Because of the different abodes, types, and degrees of detachment, there are 864.
Because of the different abodes, types, degrees of detachment, and faculties, there are 2,592.
Those who attain nirvana in the intermediate state have this many, and so do those who go upstream.
Thus there are a total of 12,960 different types of non-returners.ğŸ”½Just as the different types of non-returners who proceed to the form realm are established,
the different types of non-returners who proceed to the formless realm are also established in the same way as appropriate.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
